com.salesforce.omakase.ast.collection

Interface Groupable<P,T extends Groupable<P,T>>

  • Type Parameters:
    P - Type of the (P)arent object containing this collection (e.g., SelectorParts have Selectors as the parent).
    T - The (T)ype of units to be grouped with.
    All Superinterfaces:
    Broadcastable, Syntax, Writable
    All Known Subinterfaces:
    FunctionValue, PropertyValueMember, SelectorPart, SimpleSelector, Statement, Term
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    AbstractGroupable, AbstractSelectorPart, AbstractTerm, AtRule, AttributeSelector, ClassSelector, Combinator, Declaration, FontDescriptor, GenericFunctionValue, HexColorValue, IdSelector, KeyframeSelector, KeywordValue, LinearGradientFunctionValue, MediaQuery, MediaQueryExpression, NumericalValue, Operator, PseudoClassSelector, PseudoElementSelector, Rule, Selector, StringValue, TypeSelector, UnicodeRangeValue, UniversalSelector, UnquotedIEFilter, UrlFunctionValue

    public interface Groupable<P,T extends Groupable<P,T>>
extends Syntax
    Represents an item that appears in a group or chain of other related units, for usage with SyntaxCollection.

    Note that uniqueness within the same SyntaxCollection is enforced, which means that if you prepend or append an instance that already exists in the SyntaxCollection it will be moved. This also means that if you prepend or append an instance to a difference SyntaxCollection it will be moved out of the original collection as well. If this is not what you want then try looking at Syntax.copy().

    To remove a unit from the syntax tree, use destroy(). A destroyed unit cannot be placed back in the tree (among other reasons because it may have bypassed necessary subscription methods), however it can still be copied.

    See Also:
    SyntaxCollection

    • Method Detail

      • isFirst

        boolean isFirst()
        Gets whether this unit is the first within its group.

        Please note, if you are making decisions based on this value then keep in mind that any rework plugins may add or remove new units before or after this one. As such, this usually means it's best that plugins with Rework methods utilizing this value are registered last.

        Returns:
        True if the unit is first within its group. Always returns true if this unit is detached.

      • isLast

        boolean isLast()
        Gets whether this unit is the last within its group.

        Please note, if you are making decisions based on this value then keep in mind that any rework plugins may add or remove new units before or after this one. As such, this usually means it's best that plugins with Rework methods utilizing this value are registered last.

        Returns:
        True if the unit is last within its group. Always returns true if this unit is detached.

      • next

        Optional<T> next()
        Gets the unit following this one in the same collection, if there is one. This will always return an empty optional if this unit has not been added to any collection.
        Returns:
        The next unit, or an empty Optional if there isn't one.

      • previous

        Optional<T> previous()
        Gets the unit preceding this one in the same collection, if there is one. This will always return an empty optional if this unit has not been added to any collection.
        Returns:
        The previous unit, or an empty Optional if there isn't one.

      • prepend

        Groupable<P,T> prepend(T unit)
        Prepends the given unit before this one.

        Note that uniqueness within the same SyntaxCollection is enforced, which means that if you prepend or append an instance that already exists in the SyntaxCollection it will be moved. This also means that if you prepend or append an instance to a difference SyntaxCollection it will be moved out of the original collection as well. If this is not what you want then try looking at Syntax.copy().

        Parameters:
        unit - The unit to prepend.
        Returns:
        this, for chaining.
        Throws:
        IllegalStateException - If this unit is currently detached (doesn't belong to any collection) or it has been destroyed.

      • append

        Groupable<P,T> append(T unit)
        Appends the given unit after this one.

        Note that uniqueness within the same SyntaxCollection is enforced, which means that if you prepend or append an instance that already exists in the SyntaxCollection it will be moved. This also means that if you prepend or append an instance to a difference SyntaxCollection it will be moved out of the original collection as well. If this is not what you want then try looking at Syntax.copy().

        Parameters:
        unit - The unit to append.
        Returns:
        this, for chaining.
        Throws:
        IllegalStateException - If this unit is currently detached (doesn't belong to any group) or it has been destroyed.

      • replaceWith

        Groupable<P,T> replaceWith(T unit)
        Replaces this unit with the given one.

        Specifically, it prepends the unit to this one, then calls destroy() on this unit. Note that destroy() basically makes this unit worthless, so do not do anything with it afterwards (like trying to put it back in the tree).

        Parameters:
        unit - Replace with this unit.
        Returns:
        this, for chaining.

      • unlink

        Groupable<P,T> unlink()
        Severs the connection between this unit and its collection. Generally this method is used internally. If you want to remove a unit from the syntax tree, use destroy() instead.
        Returns:
        this, for chaining.

      • destroy

        void destroy()
        Removes this unit from its collection. Use this method to remove a unit from the syntax tree.

        Once removed, the unit cannot be re-added to any collection, however it can still be copied. Destroyed units will no longer be broadcasted to any subsequent plugins.

      • isDestroyed

        boolean isDestroyed()
        Whether the unit has been destroyed.
        Returns:
        True if the unit has been destroyed.

      • group

        Groupable<P,T> group(SyntaxCollection<P,T> group)
        Sets the group. Internal method only! Do not call directly or behavior will be unexpected.
        Parameters:
        group - The group group.
        Returns:
        this, for chaining.

      • group

        SyntaxCollection<P,T> group()
        Gets the group SyntaxCollection of this unit.

        This can be used to find all peers of the unit (e.g., all other declarations in the same rule as this one).

        Returns:
        The group SyntaxCollection. If working with this term before it has been properly linked then this may return null. This is not the case for normal subscription methods.

      • parent

        P parent()
        Gets the parent Syntax unit that owns the SyntaxCollection that contains this unit. See SyntaxCollection.parent().
        Returns:
        The parent. If working with this term before it has been properly linked then this may return null. This is not the case for normal subscription methods.
